channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: After a break from strength training, muscle memory may help you bounce back
item.description: If the season or an injury has derailed your gym routine, don't sweat it. New research shows your muscles can regain lost strength faster than you might think.
item.content:encoded:
If the season or an injury has derailed your gym routine, don't sweat it. New research shows your muscles can regain lost strength faster than you might think.

(Image credit: EyeEm Mobile GmbH/iStockphoto)
item.dc:creator: Will Stone

item.title: The price America paid for its first big immigration crackdown
item.description: The Chinese Exclusion Act was the first significant crackdown on immigration in American history. We explore the factors that led to the Act and examine what happened to the economy after it passed.
item.content:encoded:
The Chinese Exclusion Act was the first significant crackdown on immigration in American history. We explore the factors that led to the Act and examine what happened to the economy after it passed.

(Image credit: Thure de Thulstrup)
item.dc:creator: Greg Rosalsky

item.title: Trump has promised lower taxes. These are 3 ways it could impact you
item.description: From "no tax on tips" to Social Security, Donald Trump has made a range of promises about the taxes Americans will pay. We take a look at three changes we could see in the months ahead.
item.content:encoded:
From "no tax on tips" to Social Security, Donald Trump has made a range of promises about the taxes Americans will pay. We take a look at three changes we could see in the months ahead.

(Image credit: Allison Robbert)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: Dirt-cheap toys imported into U.S. can be dangerous, group says. Here's what to know
item.description: "We rarely come out and say, 'You should not do this.' But this is one of the exceptions," consumer advocate Teresa Murray says, warning against the lure of rock-bottom prices from unfamiliar sellers.
item.content:encoded:
"We rarely come out and say, 'You should not do this.' But this is one of the exceptions," consumer advocate Teresa Murray says, warning against the lure of rock-bottom prices from unfamiliar sellers.

(Image credit: Ya-Huei Laura Lee)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Angela Merkel and the future of NATO under a second Trump term
item.description: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel says she had to consider whether she is a "feminist." She joined NPR's Mary Louise Kelly to discuss her new memoir, Freedom.
item.content:encoded:
Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel says she had to consider whether she is a "feminist." She joined NPR's Mary Louise Kelly to discuss her new memoir, Freedom.

(Image credit: Mehmet Kaman)
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: Gospel-focused racial reconciliation in the Deep South
item.description: Two former leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention, one Black and one white, want to bridge the Deep South's racial divide with faith-based discussions in cities once active in the slave trade.
item.content:encoded:
Two former leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention, one Black and one white, want to bridge the Deep South's racial divide with faith-based discussions in cities once active in the slave trade.

(Image credit: Annie Flanagan for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Debbie Elliott

item.title: Mohammad Rasoulof left Iran after making his most daring film
item.description: Dissident filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof talks about how he escaped Iran on foot after making his new political thriller, The Seed of the Sacred Fig.
item.content:encoded:
The Seed of The Sacred Fig after misplacing his service weapon and resorts to using interrogation tactics on his wife and daughters.'/>

Dissident filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof talks about how he escaped Iran on foot after making his new political thriller, The Seed of the Sacred Fig.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Hampton

item.title: Formula 1 expands grid to add General Motors' Cadillac brand and new American team
item.description: The approval ends years of wrangling that launched a U.S. Justice Department investigation into why Colorado-based Liberty Media, the commercial rights holder of F1, would not approve the team.
item.content:encoded:
The approval ends years of wrangling that launched a U.S. Justice Department investigation into why Colorado-based Liberty Media, the commercial rights holder of F1, would not approve the team.

(Image credit: Matt York)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Walmart becomes latest — and biggest — company to roll back its DEI policies
item.description: Conservative groups have filed lawsuits against workplace diversity initiatives that prioritize historically marginalized groups.
item.content:encoded:
Conservative groups have filed lawsuits against workplace diversity initiatives that prioritize historically marginalized groups.

(Image credit: Steven Senne)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Supporters of ousted Pakistani leader clash with police, at least six people killed
item.description: Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds and at least one person has died in clashes.
item.content:encoded:
Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds and at least one person has died in clashes.

(Image credit: Maaz Awan)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
